qas.question: What was used to power chain pumps to raise water to irrigation ditches?
What commandery was the creator of the waterwheel-powered reciprocator from?
Who was the author of the essay entitled Balance Discourse?
During what century is it likely that the watermill made an appearance in China?
During what era did the waterwheel first appear in recordings?

context: The waterwheel appeared in Chinese records during the <a4_0>Han<a4_0/>. As mentioned by Huan Tan in about 20 AD, they were used to turn gears that lifted iron trip hammers, and were used in pounding, threshing and polishing grain. However, there is no sufficient evidence for the watermill in China until <a3_0>about the 5th century<a3_0/>. The <a1_0>Nanyang<a1_0/> Commandery Administrator Du Shi (d. 38 AD) created a waterwheel-powered reciprocator that worked the bellows for the smelting of iron. <a0_0>Waterwheels<a0_0/> were also used to power chain pumps that lifted water to raised irrigation ditches. The chain pump was first mentioned in China by the philosopher <a2_0>Wang Chong<a2_0/> in his 1st-century-AD Balanced Discourse.
